title: Graphic & type design in Washington DC area
content:
Hello,

I am a french type and graphic designer recently arrived in Washington DC, and in few weeks, I will be allowed to work in the USA.  
So, I am looking for any contact related to graphic/type design studios, galeries, bookshops, or foundries in DC area.  
I need to know more about graphic design culture here so if anybody could help me, I would be pleased.

I have already had a look on this topic:  
 [http://typophile.com/node/31239](http://web.archive.org/web/20091204034427/http:/typophile.com/node/31239 "http://typophile.com/node/31239")

Thanks in advance!
author: lucie.J

comments.content:
<cite>graphic/type design studios</cite>  
Arrange visits with Studio A, Design Army, and Grafik.

<cite>galeries</cite>  
Not much for type/design. But take advantage of the free art museums on the national mall. Drive (or take a train) to Baltimore and see the American visionary museum, the real gem of the area.

<cite>bookshops</cite>  
For a visitor there are no interesting bookstores left in the Washington area (especially if youâ€™re used to good French bookstores). If you really love American politics you might want to try Kramer Books or Politics and Prose. Second Story Books at 22nd and P in NW Washington sometimes has good used books at prices far cheaper than most stores, and now that I have left town nobody is buying up all his design books.

<cite>foundries</cite>  
There are none.

You can try connecting with the [DC AIGA](http://web.archive.org/web/20091204034427/http:/aigadc.org/). Business in DC slows almost to a halt between the middle of November and the middle of January, so this is a good time to connect with people, but make appointments in advance as many people will be on vacation.

Thank you so much James.  
I will definitely try the Second Story Books shop and get connected with the design studios.  
I am a little bit sad to hear that no foundries exist in DC, but I could guess that.

:-) !
